definitions.definition: confident that you know something or that you are right
definitions.sensetop: sure (that)…sure of somethingsure about somethingnot sure how, whether, etc…

examples.text: ‘Is that John over there?’ ‘**I'm not sure**.’
You don't sound very sure.
I'm **pretty sure** (that) he'll agree.
Are you sure you don't mind?
I’m sure he’s still alive.
I hope you are sure of your facts.
Are you sure about that?
Ask me if you're not sure how to do it.
I'm not sure whether I should tell you this.
not **exactly/entirely/absolutely/really sure**
I still **wasn't even sure **who I was talking to.
I like this bit, but I'm **not so sure **about that one.
What makes you so sure she'll come back to you?
I'm quite sure (that) I left my bag here.
Potts was confident of taking the American title, but less sure about the world championship.

definitions.definition: certain that you will receive something or that something will happen
definitions.sensetop: sure of somethingsure of doing something

examples.text: You're always sure of a warm welcome there.
We could not be sure of financial support.
England must win this game to be sure of qualifying for the World Cup.

definitions.definition: certain to do something or to happen

examples.text: The exhibition is sure to be popular.
It's sure to rain.
You’re sure to get lost if you don’t keep to the path.
She's sure to be picked for the team.

definitions.definition: that can be trusted or relied on

examples.text: It's a **sure sign** of economic recovery.
There's only one **sure way** to do it.
He is a **sure bet** for the presidential nomination *(= certain to succeed)*.
I told my friends that our winning was a sure thing.
We admired her sure touch at the keyboard.

definitions.definition: used to tell somebody to do something

examples.text: Be sure to give your family my regards.
Be sure to check out our website.
No one knows for sure what happened.
I think he'll be back on Monday, but I can't say for sure.
**One thing is for sure**—it's not going to be easy.
‘Will you be there?’ ‘For sure.’

definitions.definition: something that is likely to happen, to succeed or to be suitable

examples.text: He's a good bet to earn a spot on the US team.
Clothes are a safe bet as a present for a teenager.
The movie looks like a sure bet for Best Film.

definitions.definition: to do something in order to be certain that something else happens

examples.text: Make sure (that) no one finds out about this.
They scored another goal and made sure of victory.
Our staff will do their best to make sure you enjoy your visit.
To make doubly sure they would not be disturbed she turned the key in the lock.

definitions.definition: to check that something is true or has been done

examples.text: She looked around to make sure that she was alone.
I think the door's locked, but I'll just go and make sure.
She seems very sure of herself.

definitions.definition: used to say ‘yes’ to a suggestion or request

examples.text: ‘Are you coming?’ ‘Sure thing.’

definitions.definition: used to admit that something is true

examples.text: He is intelligent, to be sure, but he's also very lazy.

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old French sur, from Latin securus ‘free from care’.
